citeinfo.origin: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), Alaska Fisheries Science Center (AFSC)
citeinfo.title: Time Series of Biophysical Oceanographic Indices of the Southeast Alaska Coast

descript.abstract: The Southeast Alaska Coastal Monitoring (SECM) research was initiated in the spring of 1997, just prior to the onset of an El Nino event, and has continued annually through 2003. Sampling is centered around Icy Strait (58.25°N, 135.50°W) in the northern region of Southeast Alaska. This locality is the principal seaward corridor utilized by juvenile salmon migrating to the Gulf of Alaska from inside waters of the region. Sampling has been conducted monthly during up to six intervals from May to October, and at up to 24 stations spanning 250 km from inshore habitats near large glacial rivers to coastal habitats 65 km offshore in the Gulf of Alaska. Juvenile salmon and ecologically-related species have been sampled with a surface trawl from the NOAA Ship John N. Cobb. The SECM research is scheduled to continue, with increased emphasis on process studies focusing on bioenergetics and interactions of hatchery and wild stocks of juvenile salmon.
descript.purpose: To build and maintain a time series of biophysical oceanographic indices related to the seasonal growth, distribution, abundance, and habitat utilization of juvenile salmon stocks. To examine relationships between juvenile salmon and ecologically-related species.

distinfo.distliab: While every effort has been made to ensure that these data are accurate and reliable within the limits of the current state of the art, NOAA cannot assume liability for any damages caused by any errors or omissions in the data, nor as a result of the failure of the data to function on a particular system. NOAA makes no warranty, expressed or implied, nor does the fact of distribution constitute such a warranty.
